instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2330: What is 820-2330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.ADAPTER_SENSE: What is ADAPTER_SENSE? This is a line between the onewire circuit and the magsafe charger where the magsafe charger can talk to the SMC(system management controller) on the SYS_ONEWIRE line..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.ISL6258: What is ISL6258? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2008 through 2009.
definitions.CHGR_ACOK: What is CHGR_ACOK? This is identical to SMC_BC_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.CHGR_ACIN: What is CHGR_ACIN? CHGR_ACIN is a signal that is created by a voltage divider between the charger and ground that goes into the ISL6258, ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip that creates PPBUS_G3H. It is necessary for SMC_BC_ACOK & CHGR_ACOK to be present so that the onewire circuit is told to turn on & allow the SMC to speak to the charger..
definitions.CHGR_DCIN: What is CHGR_DCIN? CHGR_DCIN comes directly from charger into ISL6258 or ISL6259, the resistor before it can be blown when there are surges. Should be checked when PPBUS_G3H is missing.
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7022: What is R7022? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.
definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
Hello,
i got another problem with an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. The board has no green light. I cant measure any Voltages i want. Nothing at DCIN Fuse, no PP3V42, no <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> or <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_S5_CHGR</SIGNAL>. So i don´t know what to check next. Could it be the SMC? 
I noticed, that after i plugged my charger in i need to completely unplug it from the wall and wait few seconds until the charger will work again with a good board. If i once plug it into this it´s like a dead charger. But at other Boards it works perfectly fine - no unplug from wall needed.
I measured <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> witch jumps between +0,000V and -0,000V. At the moment i plug the charger in (only if i unplug it from the wall before, of course) i can measure at pin 1 & 2 of J6900 a spike of 0,384V for a second. Thats the only sign of life from this board. No evidence of water, soldering etc. 
Thanks for any help!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: Voltage on pin 3 from <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>? Voltage on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>???

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: Looks like a short on the DCIN bus that is why your charger is tripping. Find the short and inject some voltage to see what heats up. I assume you swapped the magsafe board already.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: No Voltage anywhere at this board. Yes i tried different DCIN boards but no success (and this DCIN board works with other boards just fine too). <TRANSISTOR>Q7065</TRANSISTOR> has 0,000V to ground at pin 1-3. Pin 4-8 are not shorted. Is that normal with no charger plugged in? As far as i can tell the only natural Part to ground from there are <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> but these should be closed with no voltage on the gate as they are n-channel (so no way to ground here) or did i miss something? Could that be the short causing this problem?.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: Is there a short to GND on L7030 too?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: On L7030 Pin 1 & 2 0,38V and Pin 3 OL, so no short there. <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> has a short (on Pin 5 0,379V), but <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> has 0,001V to GND. So the short has to be between <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7065</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: There are only 2 caps there, or in the PCB itself.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: I checked them and one was blown. I replaced it and the charger stopped tripping, but still no green light. I followed this path and my guess is that <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is bad too. I ordered some <CHIP>ISL6258</CHIP> because i only have <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> in stock. Maybe that will do it. I hope that i can do the rest alone. If i get stuck i´ll let you know. Thank you so far!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: So without measuring anything you assume <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> bad?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: Not without measuring. I came to this conclusion but i´m not sure if its right. So, after i exchanged <CAPACITOR>C7030</CAPACITOR> the short was gone and the charger was no longer tripping, but still no green light. I can hear a silent clicking sound coming permanent from the board and sometimes the green light appears for a second if i plug it in. This sound i heard not the first time and often it was a bad transistor pair of the buck converter (from my experience), so i exchanged <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> too, but still no green light.I checked <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and it  was not there. Voltage came in pin 5 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> but not out of pin 1-3 because on pin 4 was 0V. <SIGNAL>CHGR_UGATE</SIGNAL> is not there which comes from <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. Also <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL> is not there and not shorted (so no green light). I measured around and <RESISTOR>R7001</RESISTOR> is shorted on both sides too, so <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is not told to turn on. Also <RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR> has Voltage at pin 1 but a short at pin 2 and <RESISTOR>R7002</RESISTOR> is shorted on both pins too (but it should only be connected to GND on pin 2). These 3 resistors are all good, so my conclusion was that the only path to ground here is <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> (or at least 3 caps around it must he shorted). So i ordered a new <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. I hope my troubleshooting process is not completely garbage. I just don´t want to steal your time for every step that i maybe can solve myself.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: IF there is indeed a short to GND on both sides of <RESISTOR>R7001</RESISTOR> then a dead <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> would indeed be logical.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: My ordered <CHIP>ISL6258</CHIP> arrived and i soldered it in. Now there is no short on <RESISTOR>R7001</RESISTOR> anymore, but still no green light. So i need to ask you again for help. Is it normal that on <RESISTOR>R7001</RESISTOR> i measure 0V on both sides? Now <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACIN</SIGNAL> is around 3,9V but <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is not there. I noticed, that <SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> is around 1V but jumping up and down a little. Is that normal? On Pin 2 of <DIODE>D7005</DIODE> is 16.6V dipping down to 16.2V. Resistance to GND on <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is with charger plugged in around 0,03V but after i unplug the charger it slowly goes up to 0,505V. So i´m really confused again...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
"Resistance to GND on <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is with charger plugged in around 0,03V"
WOW!!!
I think somewhere in the forum presentation I've read something about this kind of measurment.
If continue like this you may burn something more...
BTW, write 030, or 505 when you use diode scale; this way is better to understand.
"<SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> is around 1V"
So <DIODE>D7005</DIODE> is burnt too; <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> killed it...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: <SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> should be 16V too. Looks like a dead <DIODE>D7005</DIODE>

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: Thanks for the replys! First of all sorry for the long time i need to answer. I´m not able to work as often on this as i like to. I wanted to do measurements yesterday but i couldn´t - so i can get back to this on monday i hope. But i already did a little research and have a question. Can the problem with <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL> occur because <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is not powered right? (<SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> not there). And is there an equivalent part to <DIODE>D7005</DIODE> on some other board? I have not the exact same Diode and can´t find a matching one.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: Any diode will work; just find one with same size...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: I replaced <DIODE>D7005</DIODE> wit another diode with equal size. Now <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is there but jumping between 1,8V and 3,3V. Diode Mode reading is 1,115V. PP3V42 is ok. Is this indicating a problem with the SMC?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: What is voltage on <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR>? PPBUS?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: PPBUS is only 0,6V. I can not find any <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR> in schematic or boardviev. Did you mean <RESISTOR>R7001</RESISTOR>? Voltage there is 5,09V on both pins. <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACIN</SIGNAL> is jumping fron 3,2V to 3,9V. <SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> is too. I learned from Louis videos that this can be related to current sensing. So i checked <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> (it was fine ~2 Ohm) and <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR>. <RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR> was 20 MOhm and <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR> was 1,8 KOhm. I replaced both and PPBUS is now back 12.6V. So <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACIN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> are now also steady 3,9V / 16.3V. Also <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is there. Its 3,27V. PP3V42 is also 3,41V. But still no green light.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: OK then the ISL circuit seems working now. Have you tried a known good magsafe board? What is voltage on pin 5 of <CHIP>U6915</CHIP>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: <CHIP>U6915</CHIP> has 16,6-16,7V at Pin 5. Is that to low.  I tested the magsafe board with a Mainboard that has not even a CPU on it and it works.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: That is fine. What is the voltage on J6900 SIG pin? <DIODE>D6900</DIODE> is suspect if SIG pin is at 3.4V

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> is 0,012V and i don´t have a oscilloscope. If i check for a short there i get OL. On a dead board with no cpu but green light i get 3.2-3.4V.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: Post voltages for <TRANSISTOR>Q6915</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: I got that Pin 2 and 5 of <TRANSISTOR>Q6920</TRANSISTOR> are 0.00V. I guess that should be higher cause <TRANSISTOR>Q6920</TRANSISTOR> is nMOS (open when gate is high). Pin 6 has >3V on it. <TRANSISTOR>Q6910</TRANSISTOR> has 6,72V at pin 2 so 16V can pass from Pin 1 to Pin 6. But <TRANSISTOR>Q6915</TRANSISTOR> is also opened. It has 8,12V at pin 5, so Pin 3 is connected to pin 4 = GND (multi meter beeps). If i disconnect the charger it is not beeping anymore , so i assume <TRANSISTOR>Q6915</TRANSISTOR> is fine and the problem is the 8V at pin 5 of <TRANSISTOR>Q6915</TRANSISTOR>. <RESISTOR>R6913</RESISTOR> - <RESISTOR>R6916</RESISTOR> are all below 270k Ohm. <CHIP>U6915</CHIP> has 8,13V at pin 1, 0V at pin 2, 0,012V at pin 3, 8,12V at pin 4 and 16,66V at pin 5. So if Pin 3 is normal (but it can´t be different as <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> is 0,012V as well and <RESISTOR>R6920</RESISTOR> is fine) i would blame <CHIP>U6915</CHIP> here.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
<CHIP>U6915</CHIP> is bad.
It should tie output to ground when pin1 is higher than pin3.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: Thank you for the confirmation. Is <CHIP>U6915</CHIP> equal to <CHIP>U5000</CHIP> of an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (It has lover in and outputs, but partnumber is the same)? I don´t have the same board here to grab parts from it

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message:
Did you even compare the 2?
LM397 is on pretty much every Apple board form 2006-2009.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: Thank you for the answer. I saw that they are different. I just asked because eg. <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> can work with different Voltages. Also i found different Datasheets and the Number which is written under "LM397" matches. My problem is that i can´t find this exact chip. I only have <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, 2915, 2850, 2936, 2877 some Air and Retina boards avaliable.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: Can i instead use a LM397MF. That is avaliable online.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: Yes          .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: OK Thank you. I ordered a few and let you know if it finally works when they arrive.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light
threads.message: LM397MF arrived, i soldered it in and now, finally, it works again. Seems like everything is fine now. Thanks for the great support!
